name: Tyrannosaurus Rex
description: One of the largest land carnivores of all time, T-Rex was a fearsome predator with a massive skull balanced by a long, heavy tail. It had the strongest bite force of any terrestrial animal that has ever lived.
funFact: T-Rex's bite force was estimated to be around 12,800 pounds, enough to crush bone.

name: Triceratops
description: A large herbivorous dinosaur with a bony frill and three horns on its skull. It was one of the last non-avian dinosaurs to evolve. The frill may have been used for display or defense.
funFact: The skull of a Triceratops could grow up to 2.5 meters (8.2 feet) in length.

name: Velociraptor
description: A small, turkey-sized dromaeosaurid dinosaur. It was a bipedal, feathered carnivore with a long tail and an enlarged sickle-shaped claw on each hindfoot.
funFact: Velociraptor was much smaller than the ones in Jurassic Park, standing only about 0.5 meters high.

name: Spinosaurus
description: The largest known carnivorous dinosaur, even larger than T-Rex. It had a massive sail on its back and was adapted for a semi-aquatic lifestyle, hunting fish.
funFact: Spinosaurus is the first dinosaur known to have been able to swim.

name: Ankylosaurus
description: A heavily armored dinosaur with a large club at the end of its tail. It was a low-slung herbivore built like a living tank.
funFact: Its eyelids were even armored with bone.

name: Parasaurolophus
description: Known for its large, elaborate cranial crest, which formed a long curved tube projecting upwards and back from the skull. It likely used this crest for sound amplification.
funFact: Computer simulations suggest its crest could produce low-frequency sounds like a foghorn.

name: Carnotaurus
description: A large theropod dinosaur with distinctive bull-like horns above its eyes. It had extremely small vestigial forelimbs and was built for speed.
funFact: Its name means 'meat-eating bull'.

name: Pteranodon
description: A genus of pterosaur that included some of the largest known flying reptiles, with wingspans over 6 meters (20 feet). They were not dinosaurs, but flying reptiles that lived alongside them.
funFact: Pteranodon means 'wing without tooth'.

name: Stegosaurus
description: A herbivorous dinosaur known for the distinctive upright plates along its back and spikes on its tail. It had a very small brain for its body size.
funFact: The spikes on its tail are often called a 'thagomizer'.

name: Brachiosaurus
description: A gigantic sauropod dinosaur with longer front legs than hind legs, giving it a giraffe-like stance. It was one of the tallest dinosaurs to ever live.
funFact: Unlike most other sauropods, Brachiosaurus likely held its neck high, browsing on tall trees.

name: Allosaurus
description: A large bipedal predator. Its skull was large and equipped with dozens of sharp, serrated teeth. It was the apex predator of the Morrison Formation.
funFact: Allosaurus could open its jaws extremely wide, possibly to use its upper jaw like a hatchet.

name: Diplodocus
description: One of the longest dinosaurs, with a unique body shape, long neck and tail, and four sturdy legs. Its tail was extremely long and whip-like.
funFact: It could likely crack its tail like a whip, creating a sonic boom.

name: Archaeopteryx
description: Often considered the first bird, Archaeopteryx is a transitional fossil between non-avian dinosaurs and birds. It had feathers and wings but also teeth and a long bony tail.
funFact: The Berlin Specimen is one of the most famous fossils in the world.

name: Iguanodon
description: A large herbivore that could shift from bipedal to quadrupedal movement. It had a distinctive large thumb spike, which was likely used for defense against predators.
funFact: It was one of the first three dinosaurs ever named.

name: Dimetrodon
description: Often mistaken for a dinosaur, Dimetrodon was actually a synapsid, a mammal-like reptile that lived millions of years before the first dinosaurs. It had a large sail on its back.
funFact: The sail was likely used for thermoregulation, helping it warm up or cool down.

name: Woolly Mammoth
description: Ideally adapted to the ice age environment, these massive elephants were covered in thick fur and possessed long, curved tusks.
funFact: The last population of woolly mammoths lived on Wrangel Island until 1650 BC.

name: Saber-toothed Tiger
description: Famous for its long, curved canine teeth which could reach up to 28 cm. It was a robust predator built for wrestling prey to the ground.
funFact: Despite the name, they are not closely related to modern tigers.

name: Dunkleosteus
description: A massive armored fish that was one of the first apex predators in the fossil record. Instead of teeth, it had sharp bony plates that acted like shears.
funFact: It could open its mouth in 1/50th of a second, creating a vacuum that sucked prey in.

name: Anomalocaris
description: The first known super-predator, this alien-looking creature had stalked eyes, two grasping appendages, and a circular mouth. It dominated the Cambrian seas.
funFact: Its name means 'abnormal shrimp' because its parts were originally thought to be separate animals.

name: Megalodon
description: The largest shark that ever lived. It is known primarily from its giant teeth, which can be over 7 inches long. It likely preyed on whales.
funFact: Its bite force was estimated to be up to 40,000 pounds, 3 times stronger than a T-Rex.

name: Dodo
description: A flightless bird that lived on the island of Mauritius. Its fearlessness of humans and inability to fly made it easy prey for sailors and invasive species.
funFact: The Dodo is related to pigeons and doves.

name: Titanoboa
description: The largest snake ever discovered, reaching lengths of up to 12.8 meters (42 ft). It lived in the tropical rainforests of South America shortly after the extinction of the dinosaurs.
funFact: It was so large it would have had to spend much of its time in water to support its weight.

name: Mosasaurus
description: A colossal marine reptile that ruled the Late Cretaceous seas. It was not a dinosaur but a lizard, closely related to modern monitor lizards and snakes.
funFact: It had a second row of teeth in the roof of its mouth to hold onto slippery prey.

name: Glyptodon
description: A giant armored mammal related to armadillos. It was roughly the size and weight of a Volkswagen Beetle and carried a massive domed shell.
funFact: Indigenous people may have used their empty shells as shelters.

name: Megatherium
description: A giant ground sloth that was one of the largest land mammals known. It could stand on its hind legs to reach high branches and was likely slow-moving.
funFact: It was one of the few land mammals large enough to have few natural predators when fully grown.

name: Plesiosaurus
description: A marine reptile with a broad body, short tail, and long neck. It swam using four flippers and likely hunted fish and belemnites.
funFact: It is often associated with the Loch Ness Monster legend, though they went extinct 66 million years ago.

name: Quetzalcoatlus
description: One of the largest flying animals of all time, this pterosaur had a wingspan of up to 11-12 meters (36-39 ft). It likely stalked prey on land like a giant stork.
funFact: When standing on the ground, it was as tall as a modern giraffe.

discovery.where: Big Bend National Park, Texas, USA

name: Thylacine
description: Also known as the Tasmanian Tiger, it was the largest carnivorous marsupial of modern times. It had a stiff tail and abdominal pouch (in both sexes).
funFact: It could open its jaws to an unusually wide angle of 120 degrees.

name: Pachycephalosaurus
description: Famous for its thick, domed skull which could be up to 25 cm thick. It was a bipedal herbivore that may have used its head for display or combat.
funFact: Its name means 'thick-headed lizard'.

name: Deinosuchus
description: A gigantic prehistoric crocodile that grew up to 10-12 meters long. It had teeth the size of bananas and likely preyed on dinosaurs.
funFact: Its bite force is estimated to have been even stronger than T-Rex's.

name: Arthropleura
description: The largest known land invertebrate of all time, this giant millipede could reach 2.5 meters in length. It lived in oxygen-rich swamp forests.
funFact: It likely had few predators due to its massive size and tough exoskeleton.

name: Argentavis
description: The largest flying bird ever discovered, with a wingspan of up to 7 meters (23 ft). This massive bird of prey soared over the Argentinian plains millions of years ago.
funFact: It was so large that it likely couldn't flap its wings much and instead relied on soaring like modern condors.

name: Basilosaurus
description: Despite its name meaning 'king lizard', this was actually an early whale. It had a serpentine body up to 18 meters long and small vestigial hind legs.
funFact: Its scientific name is misleading - it was named before scientists realized it was a mammal, not a reptile.

name: Giganotosaurus
description: One of the largest known terrestrial carnivores, rivaling T-Rex in size. It had a massive skull and powerful jaws built for hunting large prey.
funFact: Its brain was shaped like a banana and was relatively small for body size.

name: Elasmosaurus
description: A marine reptile famous for its extremely long neck, which contained over 70 vertebrae - more than any other known animal. It used its neck to hunt fish in ancient seas.
funFact: When first described, the head was mistakenly placed on the tail end, a mistake that took years to correct.

name: Helicoprion
description: A bizarre shark-like fish best known for its unique whorl of teeth that formed a spiral in its lower jaw. It used this unusual structure to slice prey.
funFact: For over a century, scientists couldn't figure out where the tooth whorl was located on its body - many thought it was on the snout or dorsal fin!

name: Therizinosaurus
description: A colossal herbivore with the longest claws of any known animal, reaching up to 1 meter (3.3 ft) in length. Despite its terrifying appearance, it was a gentle giant that used its claws to pull down vegetation.
funFact: Its name means 'scythe lizard', referring to its massive claws.

name: Baryonyx
description: A fish-eating dinosaur with a crocodile-like snout and a large hooked claw on its thumb. It likely waded in shallow water to catch slippery prey.
funFact: It was the first carnivorous dinosaur discovered to have a fish-eating diet.

name: Microraptor
description: A tiny, four-winged dinosaur that could glide between trees. It had long flight feathers on both its arms and legs, making it one of the most unusual dinosaurs ever found.
funFact: Its iridescent black feathers suggest it may have looked like a crow.

name: Tiktaalik
description: A crucial transitional fossil between fish and tetrapods (four-limbed land animals). It had fins with wrists, allowing it to prop itself up in shallow water or on land.
funFact: It is often called a 'fishapod' because it shares characteristics of both fish and tetrapods.

name: Hallucigenia
description: A small, worm-like creature with seven pairs of long spines on its back and seven pairs of tentacles for legs. It is one of the strangest animals from the Cambrian Explosion.
funFact: Scientists originally reconstructed it upside down, thinking its spines were legs!

name: Coelophysis
description: A small, slender, bipedal carnivore that was one of the earliest dinosaurs. It was built for speed and agility.
funFact: Thousands of Coelophysis skeletons were found together at Ghost Ranch, New Mexico.

name: Plateosaurus
description: A bipedal herbivore with a long neck and tail. It was one of the first large dinosaurs and a predecessor to the giant sauropods.
funFact: It could likely switch between walking on two legs and four legs.

name: Liopleurodon
description: A massive marine reptile with four powerful flippers. It was an apex predator of the Jurassic seas.
funFact: Its teeth were up to 4 inches long.

name: Sarcosuchus
description: Known as 'SuperCroc', this was a gigantic relative of crocodiles that lived alongside dinosaurs. It had a long snout ending in a distinct bowl shape.
funFact: It grew up to 12 meters (40 ft) long and weighed up to 8 tons.

name: Opabinia
description: A bizarre creature with five eyes and a long, flexible nozzle ending in a claw. It is one of the most famous oddities of the Burgess Shale.
funFact: When its reconstruction was first presented, the audience laughed because it looked so strange.

name: Dimorphodon
description: A medium-sized pterosaur with a large, bulky skull and two distinct types of teeth. It had a relatively short wingspan compared to later pterosaurs.
funFact: Its name means 'two-form tooth' because it had different teeth in the front and back of its jaw.

name: Styracosaurus
description: A herbivorous dinosaur with a massive skull featuring a long nose horn and a frill spiked with four to six long parietal spikes.
funFact: It had one of the most distinctive skull displays of any dinosaur, likely used for display and defense.

name: Andrewsarchus
description: A giant carnivorous mammal, known only from a single massive skull. It is believed to be related to hippos and whales, but looked like a giant wolf-pig hybrid.
funFact: Its skull is 83 cm long, twice the size of a grizzly bear's.

name: Meganeura
description: An extinct insect related to dragonflies. With a wingspan of up to 75 cm (2.5 ft), it was one of the largest known flying insects to ever live.
funFact: It was a predator that likely fed on other insects and small amphibians.

name: Postosuchus
description: An apex predator of the Triassic, this rauisuchid archosaur looked like a crocodile that walked on long, erect legs. It hunted early dinosaurs.
funFact: It was the top predator in North America before theropod dinosaurs took over.
